title: How do swipe card machines process inflight purchases? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends on the flight and airline. Airlines which have in-flight internet like Gogo likely authorize the transaction in flight using that internet connection, but planes which do not have in-flight internet do not piggy back any other data via existing radio-based communications. They simply store-and-forward the transaction until the plane lands and they can get a live authorization. But what about declines? They simply take the risk that on a low ticket transaction of an in-flight purchase it will clear. Passengers don't know it's not authorizing in realtime, so they generally won't hand over a card that they know would decline.

It doesn't require much bandwidth to send and receive the data necessary to create a credit card transaction.  There's data being sent to and from airplanes constantly.  Adding credit card processing data onto that stream would barely register. What protocol is used in sending that data is a good question. It could be via radio, internet, etc.  There are a few different options, though I'm not sure of the most commonly used one.
